answer_html: \(\displaystyle f''(2) \approx \frac{f'(2.25)-f'(1.75)}{2.25-1.75} = 0.08\)and this completes the question.
hints_html: Remember that the derivative is the slope of the tangent line of a function at a point on the function. What would be a good way to estimate this line? Try drawing a picture to give you an idea.
hints_latex:
Remember that the derivative is the slope of the tangent line of a
function at a point on the function. What would be a good way to
estimate this line? Try drawing a picture to give you an idea.
hints_raw: Remember that the derivative is the slope of the tangent line of a function at a point on the function. What would be a good way to estimate this line? Try drawing a picture to give you an idea.
question: 1 (a) i
sols_html:
Given the data we have, the best way to approximate the derivative is by using secant lines! For an example, let’s first estimate \(\displaystyle f'(1.25)\). For this, lets use the secant line from x=1 and x=1.5. This gives

\(\displaystyle f'(1.25) \approx \frac{f(1.5)-f(1)}{1.5-1} = \frac{1.06-1.12}{0.5} = \frac{-0.06}{0.5} = -0.12\).

Proceeding as above, we can fill in the table as follows:

:{ style=“text-align:center; padding: 10px; border-collapse: collapse;” style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px”x style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px”1.25 style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px”1.75 style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px”2.25 style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px”2.75 - style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px”f\(^{\prime}\)(x) style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px” -0.12 style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px” -0.08 style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px” -0.04 style=“padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px” 0.06 }

For the second derivative, we use the same logic above except we do it with the derivative as our function. This gives

\(\displaystyle f''(2) \approx \frac{f'(2.25)-f'(1.75)}{2.25-1.75} = \frac{-0.04-(-0.08)}{0.5} = \frac{0.04}{0.5} = 0.08\)

and this completes the question.

sols_raw:
Given the data we have, the best way to approximate the derivative is by using secant lines! For an example, let's first estimate <math> \displaystyle f'(1.25) </math>. For this, lets use the secant line from ''x''=1 and ''x''=1.5. This gives

<math> \displaystyle f'(1.25) \approx \frac{f(1.5)-f(1)}{1.5-1} = \frac{1.06-1.12}{0.5} = \frac{-0.06}{0.5} = -0.12 </math>.

Proceeding as above, we can fill in the table as follows:

|style="padding: 5px; border-style: solid; border-width: 1px"| 0.06
|}

For the second derivative, we use the same logic above except we do it with the derivative as our function. This gives

<math> \displaystyle f''(2) \approx \frac{f'(2.25)-f'(1.75)}{2.25-1.75} = \frac{-0.04-(-0.08)}{0.5} = \frac{0.04}{0.5} = 0.08 </math>

and this completes the question.
